title: Don’t put frozen peas on an injury, and four other pieces of health advice you can now ignore
text:
As any parent, teacher, or accident-prone person will know, when a head gets bumped, it’s time to reach for the frozen peas.

However, putting ice on an injury may actually delay healing, according to the scientist who came up with the term RICE, which stands for Rest, Ice, Compression and Elevation. Dr Gabe Mirkin came up with the acronym in 1978 and it quickly became the standard treatment for twisted ankles, bumped shins and sore muscles.

But Mirkin recently told an Australian newspaper that a cold compression could “delay healing”, despite being a “safe pain medicine”. As a result, the Chartered Society of Physiotherapy (CSP) now says medics should stop using ice for bruises and sprains,...
